items.Video_Title: Why everything you buy is worse now
items.Video_Description:
From clothes to tech, why is everything so poorly made?

Subscribe and turn on notifications 🔔  so you don't miss any videos: http://goo.gl/0bsAjO 

Maybe you’ve noticed: In the past 10 years everything we buy from clothes to technology has gotten just a little bit worse. Sweaters are more likely to tear. Phones are more likely to break. Smart toasters and TVs burn out and die after only a few years. It might seem like consumer products just aren’t built to last anymore. What’s going on?

Unfortunately (and fortunately!), part of the problem is us. For decades, we’ve been conditioned to buy, buy, buy, and today it’s normal for many consumers to shop for new clothes at least once a month. In order to keep up, many companies have to prioritize making things in the fastest and least expensive way possible. To do that, they cut corners with materials and labor. In turn, quality suffers, which leaves consumers with a lot of crappy things.

The story with technology is a little different. And the biggest difference is that while no one in fashion is saying you’re not allowed to sew a new button on a shirt, many tech companies have actually made it impossible to repair their products. 

The good news is consumers have a surprising amount of control over this situation. Watch the video to learn more.


Check out the original article from Izzie Ramirez on Vox.com: https://www.vox.com/the-goods/23529587/consumer-goods-quality-fast-fashion-technology

Repair.org is Gay Gordon Byrne’s association that’s fighting for your right to repair. 

For more on the right to repair bill in New York State there are some articles here:
https://www.engadget.com/new-york-right-to-repair-law-kathy-hochul-184654713.html
https://www.theverge.com/2022/12/29/23530733/right-to-repair-law-new-york-tech-hochul-oems-parts

While I didn’t spend much time on Fast Fashion for this piece, I did love these articles:
https://catapult.co/stories/haley-e-d-houseman-clothing-costs-labor-materials-handmade-homemade-factory-made
https://www.wired.com/story/fast-cheap-out-of-control-inside-rise-of-shein/

This article from Vogue did a great job breaking down what things actually costs:
https://www.vogue.com/article/what-is-the-right-price-for-fashion

I also highly recommend following Cora Harrington (@lingerie_addict) and Derek Guy (@dieworkwear) on twitter for more hot takes on the fashion industry. 

Make sure you never miss behind the scenes content in the Vox Video newsletter, sign up here: http://vox.com/video-newsletter

items.Video_Title: 🇺🇸 Fast Fashion Lifestyle in USA.
items.Video_Description:
It's only been a few years since this Hassan Minhaj video came out (Fast Fashion episode on Netflix).  

We now have 2 new brands dumping high-speed fashion clothing into the USA. 
At an alarming rate, Americans are buying and shipping out unwanted clothing. It was still unwanted when it was bought. 😂 

Some clothing has not been thrown away yet. It's still in the closet. 
A moment in your click, forever in your closet. 😂 

btw, what did you buy for Deepavali? 

❤️ Hobby Explorer

Consider watching: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xGF3ObOBbac

items.Video_Title: That $7 Shirt Is Making You Sick: Fast Fashion vs. the World | Dark History with Bailey Sarian
items.Video_Description:
Hi friends, happy Thursday!

Welcome to the Dark History podcast.  I feel like there is a new trend every two days. And I do not know how to keep up. And by the time I figure it out, I’m already like four trends behind. But I just don’t know how people are buying these trends so quickly. How are people staying on top of all these new clothes we need every week? And turns out the answer is a little thing known as “fast fashion”. In today’s episode, we get into fast fashion. It’s been around for longer than you think and its impact and damage are even more than you think. Sorry babe, but you’re gonna take a real hard look at your closet after this one.

I appreciate you for coming by, and tune in next week for more Dark History.

items.Video_Title: How TikTok is Fueling Overconsumption
items.Video_Description:
Microtrends and 'TikTok made me buy it' culture is getting out of control, and it's only getting worse. Let's talk about how TikTok is fueling overconsumption, the way wasteful consumerism has crept into our feeds, and who profits from all of this.

Are you addicted to TikTok? Do you find yourself scrolling endlessly through videos, inspired by the latest fashion trends, makeup routines, or home decor hacks? Well, you're not alone. TikTok has become a cultural phenomenon, with millions of users worldwide, but there's a dark side to this social media platform that's causing serious harm to our planet and our wallets.

In this video, we'll explore how TikTok is fueling overconsumption and contributing to the global environmental crisis (and a drain on your finances!). We'll delve into why influencers are motivated to fuel trends, how the platform benefits, and how TikTok has completely changed the fashion industry.

items.Video_Title: How Is Shein Really Keeping Prices So Low? | WSJ The Economics Of
items.Video_Description:
Shein says it’s able to make affordable apparel by monitoring user behavior to predict customer demand and producing items in small quantities. The Chinese e-commerce company known for its $5 T-shirts and $20 cocktail dresses controls 40% of the fast-fashion market share in the U.S., with an estimated $8 billion in sales in the country last year. Shein’s inventory turnover rate is twice as fast as other competitor retailers such as H&M and Zara.

WSJ explains how Shein has dominated the global fast-fashion market as it remains one of the least transparent fast fashion companies in the world.

items.Video_Title: CNN In-Depth: Dampak Gelimang Fast Fashion
items.Video_Description:
Ganti musim, ganti model baju, ganti musim, beli koleksi baju baru lagi. Gonta ganti koleksi baju mengikuti trend terkini merupakan salah satu ciri fast fashion. Meski memiliki kontribusi besar terhadap ekonomi global, industri fast fashion juga dibayangi sejumlah dampak negatif dari sisi lingkungan maupun isu eksploitasi tenaga kerja murah. 

Menurut UNEP, industri fast fashion merupakan salah satu sektor penyumbang emisi karbon maupun pencemaran air dunia. Tak hanya menghasilkan limbah saat proses produksi, pakaian bekas pakai dari bahan sintetis -berbahan dasar minyak bumi- yang dibuang atau dibakar tanpa pengolahan yang benar juga berpotensi menimbulkan pencemaran lingkungan maupun gangguan kesehatan. 

Agar tetap dapat tampil modis sekaligus berpartisipasi menjaga lingkungan, kita dapat menerapkan gaya hidup slow fashion atau sustainable fashion dengan cara membeli dan menggunakan produk produk pakaian yang awet dari bahan bahan  ramah lingkungan.

items.Video_Title: Les ravages de la "fast fashion" - Le dessous des cartes - L'essentiel | ARTE
items.Video_Description:
Les grandes enseignes de la mode embauchent à bas coût, souvent en Asie, pour produire toujours plus et toujours plus vite. Récemment, Zara et H&M ont voulu redorer leur image en se lançant dans la vente de seconde main. Mais les délocalisations continuent de s’étendre à de nouveaux pays (par ex l’Éthiopie), et la fast fashion de mettre en péril notre environnement. Les montagnes de vieux vêtements polluent également. Plus de la moitié des habits à recycler atterrissent en Afrique, principalement au Ghana. Le pays reçoit chaque jour 160 tonnes de déchets textiles. Faisant de sa capitale Accra la poubelle de nos garde-robe. Sortons nos cartes.

#FastFashion #FastFahionImpact #VetementsPollution

items.Video_Title: Fast Fashion in der Wüste | ARTE Re:
items.Video_Description:
In der Atacama-Wüste im Norden Chiles landet, was in Europa nicht mehr gewollt ist: Kleidung, die kaum getragen oder sogar nagelneu ist. Das Land ist seit Jahren ein Umschlagplatz für Textilien aus der ganzen Welt. Was unverkauft bleibt, wird im Wüstensand verscharrt oder verbrannt – mit fatalen Folgen für Anwohner und Umwelt.

Mitten in der Atacama-Wüste im Norden Chiles ist der 38-jährige Juan Jose Saldana auf der Suche nach Müll. Genauer nach Kleidung, die illegal in der Region verklappt wird. Saldana will den Menschen zeigen, welche negativen Auswirkungen das Fast-Fashion-Geschäft auf seine Heimat hat. Denn hier landet, was im Globalen Norden nicht gewollt ist: Ladenhüter und kaum getragene Kleidung, im Sand verscharrt, verbrannt oder einfach weggeworfen.
Die Textilien stammen vor allem aus Europa und den USA. Importeure bringen sie über die Freihandelszone im Norden Chiles ins Land, mit dem Ziel, sie auf dem südamerikanischen Kontinent zu verkaufen. Doch längst nicht alles lässt sich weiterverwerten. Aber weil es in Chile an politischen Kontrollen fehlt, bezahlen Importeure lokale Fahrer, um die Kleidung illegal in die Wüste zu bringen. „Sie wollen es loswerden und schicken es nach Südamerika“, klagt Juan Jose Saldana.
Währenddessen liegt Fast-Fashion-Mode in der spanischen Hauptstadt Madrid voll im Trend. Modedesign-Studentin María Rodriguez Mateo weiß, dass ihr Kaufverhalten schlecht für die Umwelt ist. Dennoch sieht sie die Verantwortung bei den Herstellern: „Wer damit Geld verdient, sollte auch Lösungen anbieten.“

Reportage (D 2022, 33 Min)


#fastfashion #atacama #müll

Shein : les dessous de la marque chinoise au succès fou
items.Video_Description:
L’entreprise chinoise de mode en ligne Shein a installé une boutique éphémère en plein cœur de Paris, vendredi 5 mai. Situé dans le Marais, ce point de vente est aussi peu durable que les vêtements de Shein : il sera ouvert pour quatre jours seulement. Le géant de la « fast fashion » promet aux consommateurs des « prix de ouf » avec une « sélection de produits à moins de cinq euros ». 
Créée en 2008, l’entreprise a connu un succès fulgurant à partir de 2019, alors que la crise liée au Covid-19 et les confinements stimulent le e-commerce. Selon le cabinet de  conseil Kantar, en 2022, le site est le premier lieu d’achat d’habillement des 15-24 ans. Au grand dam des militants de la cause environnementale ou des droits humains. Shein a déjà fait l’objet de plusieurs polémiques sur son non-respect des droits humains dans les ateliers des sous-traitants qu’elle fait travailler, l’impact environnemental de ses vêtements en polyester ou le marketing qui promeut la surconsommation.

00:00 Fast Fashion Introduction

It’s no secret that clothing has become cheaper and easier to come by than ever before. Manufacturers have stepped in to meet the desire for instant gratification, resulting in clothing that has an extremely low price tag but often has poor craftsmanship & inferior materials.

00:23 What is Fast fashion?

The term was first coined in the early 1990s when the high street brand Zara arrived in New York City. Although Zara may be credited with the origin of the term “fast fashion”, its true origins can be traced back far earlier than the ‘90s. 

Fast fashion has shown no sign of slowing down in recent years. In its current context, fast fashion is very much like fast food in that it’s designed to be inexpensive, convenient, and consumed quickly.

04:43 The Concerns of Fast Fashion

→ The sheer volume and frequency of cheap clothing being made every year puts a significant strain on the environment.
→ Fast fashion garments are typically assembled from components originating in many different locations. These all have to be shipped to the garment manufacturer, and many of the factories that produce fast fashion clothing are based in developing countries, often far from the clothing’s intended destination.
→ Many companies have been put under scrutiny for perpetuating poor working conditions and low pay for the workers assembling the clothing
→ These brands plagiarize the work of high-end designers

08:33 Is ALL Fast Fashion Bad?

By its very nature, fast fashion clothing will simply be far less expensive than high-end, high-quality clothing such as a bespoke suit. Being able to experiment with different styles, colors, and details on a suit that costs $100 instead of several thousand dollars allows your sense of style to develop. 

The convenience fast fashion provides is also undeniable and can be an excellent remedy if you have a clothing emergency.

11:44 How to Incorporate Fast Fashion WELL

It’s all about being selective with what you choose to wear. As a classic style enthusiast, you’ll already have an eye for what you do and don’t like, and it’s important to remember that not all fast fashion is “high” fashion. There are also items within fast fashion that can seamlessly blend with a more classically inspired wardrobe. 

16:49 Conclusion

It’s convenient and instantly enjoyable, but isn’t the healthiest option. However, when incorporated into an otherwise healthy diet and in moderation, it’s unlikely to do you any lasting damage. Fast fashion provides a stepping stone that fuels interest in classic menswear early on in our individual style journeys. Fast fashion can fit the bill in the right circumstances.

18:08 Outfit Rundown

items.Video_Title: Let's Talk Fashion-  Sustainable and Fast Fashion
items.Video_Description:
Fast fashion is a booming industry that produces trendy, affordable clothing at lightning-fast speed. However, the harmful effects of fast fashion are often overlooked. The production and consumption of fast fashion have detrimental impacts on the environment, human rights, and animal welfare.

Firstly, the fast fashion industry is responsible for a massive amount of pollution. The production process of textiles involves a significant amount of water, energy, and chemicals. The fashion industry is the second-largest polluter globally, after the oil and gas industry. The fast fashion industry produces enormous amounts of waste, as clothes are often designed to be worn only a few times before being discarded.

Secondly, fast fashion is built on exploitative labor practices. Workers in fast fashion factories are often paid very low wages and work in unsafe conditions. Many workers in developing countries face verbal and physical abuse and are denied the right to unionize. Additionally, fast fashion brands often outsource their production to countries with less stringent labor laws, which exacerbates the problem.

Finally, the fast fashion industry is also complicit in animal cruelty. Many fashion items, such as fur coats, are made from animals that are bred and raised in inhumane conditions. Leather production also has significant environmental impacts, as it requires vast amounts of water and chemicals.

Overall, the harms of fast fashion cannot be overstated. The environmental, social, and ethical consequences of our consumption of fast fashion are severe, and we must take action to address them. By reducing our consumption of fast fashion and supporting sustainable and ethical alternatives, we can help create a more just and sustainable world.

items.Video_Title: How Fast Fashion Kills: Slave Labour, Toxic Waste and Catastrophic Pollution | Fashion Documentary
items.Video_Channel_Title: Java Discover | Free Global Documentaries & Clips
items.Video_Description:
The planet is being overwhelmed with clothes. Close to 56 million tonnes of clothes are sold every year. In Europe, the amount purchased has almost doubled since the year 2000. Thanks to fast disposable fashion, you can constantly renew your wardrobe. But producing clothes at such a low price has a very high environmental cost. Textiles are the second most polluting industry in the world, after oil.

Creating a dress for ten euros in Europe, in less than a fortnight. It’s not only possible, but it’s becoming the norm. Since the fashion industry went down the path of fast fashion, it’s always both faster and cheaper – no matter the consequences.

Let’s start with those suffering the most: the workers. They work between 12 and 15 hours a day for salaries less than half the legal minimum wage. And in abominable working conditions. Chemical products in textile factories often poison the workers and local residents.

According to the brands, they no longer have time to create. In order to satisfy an insatiable consumer appetite, copying the competition’s models makes things go faster and cheaper – even if it means risking a court case now and then.

items.Video_Title: HOW I STOPPED BUYING FAST FASHION (and why you should too)
items.Video_Description:
Over the past year, I’ve reevaluated my consumption habits when it comes to fast fashion and have decided that I am no longer buying it. I have always bought new clothes as well as thrifted and vintage clothes, but I never really questioned my own practices until recently. I started educating myself on exactly what goes on in the fast fashion industry, from dangerous and inhumane working conditions for people who make the garments that I buy in stores and online, to detrimental environmental impacts that are killing our planet. I can’t justify buying fast fashion for these reasons alone.

The main point I wanted to make with this video is that this change I’ve made has not had a negative impact on my life at all. Even though I don’t live near a large city with access to cool thrift stores and vintage stores, by shopping on Poshmark I’m still able to buy clothes I want for an affordable price without contributing to the fast fashion industry. I want to explain how I made this switch and how I think it’s doable for most people to shop more sustainably if they put their minds to it.

items.Video_Title: #90 - FAST-FASHION : DÉLOCALISATIONS ET POLLUTIONS ? JULIA FAURE
items.Video_Description:
🔥 Le Greenletter Club est 100% indépendant, pour nous aider, c'est ici 👉 https://bit.ly/3ppLx68

Teintures toxiques, déchets plastiques et pollutions à gogo : la Fast-fashion produit d’immenses quantités de vêtements à l’autre bout du monde, détruisant des emplois au Nord et l’environnement au Sud. D’où cette question, la Fast-fashion est-elle un fléau écolo ?

Pour y répondre, nous recevons Julia Faure, cofondatrice de Loom, une marque de vêtements éthique et de l’association en mode climat, qui réunit près de 600 entreprises pour demander des législations écologiques et sociales plus strictes pour la production de textile.  

Pour donner à l'association en mode climat, c'est ici 👉  http://bit.ly/3lKqxFy

Interview réalisée par Maxime Thuillez. 

***

00:44 - Bonjour Julia Faure, est-ce que tu peux expliquer ce qu'est Loom, et quels sont vos objectifs avec le collectif "En mode climat" ? 
02:19 - Qu'est-ce que la fast-fashion ?
04:46 - Comment et quand émerge la fast-fashion ? A quelle point est-elle puissante dans le secteur de la mode aujourd'hui ? 
08:03 - A-t-on une idée précise d'où viennent les vêtements en France et en Europe ? 
09:20 - Comment a évoluée notre consommation de vêtements ces dernières années ? On a l'impression que l'on a encore et toujours plus d'habits ? 
10:30 - La qualité des vêtements s'est-elle dégradée ? 
15:12 - Pourquoi consomme-t-on deux fois plus de vêtements qu'il y a encore 30 ou 40 ans ? 
15:56 - Toutes les grandes marques de la fast-fashion ont des programmes pour récolter des vêtements usagés, produisent des vêtements recyclés... est-ce qu'on peut croire dans ces initiatives ? 
20:55 - Quel est l'impact écologique de la mode aujourd'hui ? Les plus gros impacts ils sont en matières de CO2, de pollutions, de déchets ? 
25:09 - A quoi ressemblent les déchets issus de la mode et de la fast-fashion en fin de vie ? 
28:27 - 70% des fibres textiles aujourd'hui, c'est du polyester... et on constate que. la pollution plastique dans les océans, elle vient en majorité des vêtements. Du lavage de nos vêtements en plastique dans nos machines, mais aussi dans ces pays là, les décharges à ciel ouvert, qui voient nos vêtements en plastique jetés directement dans les rivières ou dans la mer. 
32:55 - Quelles sont les conséquences sociales de la fast-fashion dans les pays du Sud ? sur l'emploi, les modes de vie ? 
34:51 - A quoi ressemble notre industrie textile en France ,en Europe ? Le nombre d'emplois lié au textile s'est effondré sur tout le continent ? 
39:58 - Que faudrait-il faire pour relioaliser la production de textile en Europe et en France ? 
45:35 - Dans ces pays-là, en Italie, au Portugal, il y a encore une production textile vivace ?
46:29 - Tu es allée au Bangladesh dans le cadre du documentaire d'Hugo Clément... qu'est-ce qui t'a marqué là-bas ?

items.Video_Title: Shein Haul: Leiden für Fast Fashion auf TikTok | Reportage 2023 | Kassensturz | SRF
items.Video_Description:
Der Shein Haul auf TikTok: Die Billigmode von Fast Fashion Produzent Shein begeistert die junge Kundschaft. Den Preis zahlen chinesische Arbeitskräfte und die Umwelt. Die Modemarke setzt fürs Marketing auf Instagram, Tiktok & Co.: Influencerinnen erhalten Kleider gratis, wenn diese sich online darin präsentieren. Und auch viele zahlende Kundinnen und Kunden machen auf Social Media Werbung, mit sogenannten Shein-Hauls: Videos, in denen sie ihre Kleider vor der Kamera auspacken und anprobieren.

Eine SRF Reportage von Felicitas Flohr

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Für mehr solche Reportagen abonniere uns hier:
🔔 https://www.youtube.com/SRFKassensturz?sub_confirmation=1

Den Artikel zum Video findest du hier:
📰 https://www.srf.ch/sendungen/kassensturz-espresso/kassensturz/shein-problem-billigstmode-shein-75-stunden-woche-1-tag-frei-pro-monat

Playlist mit weiteren Reportagen:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL5D55kGlI1RIqluqWbrdaiN0yvoWboAai

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

► Jeden Mittwoch: Unabhängige Produkte- und Dienstleistungs-Tests

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Kassensturz ist das unabhängige Magazin für Produkte- und Dienstleistungs-Tests in den Bereichen Konsum, Geld und Arbeit. Einfach und witzig aufbereitete Fakten, klare Meinungen und freche Fragen an Produkt-Verantwortliche.

Wir vergleichen die meistverkauften Produkte mit verschiedenen Kriterien und präsentieren die detaillierten Testresultate im Fernsehen und online.

items.Video_Title: Il VERO PREZZO del fast fashion: l'impatto dei nostri vestiti sui paesi più poveri
items.Video_Description:
Hai mai sentito parlare dei “vestiti dell'uomo bianco morto”? Così in Ghana sono chiamati gli abiti di seconda mano. Sono gli indumenti che i paesi industrializzati scartano, raccolgono e spediscono verso i paesi in via di sviluppo. Ma dietro questo mercato si nasconde uno dei più grandi sistemi di produzione capitalistici: l’industria del fast fashion.

items.Video_Title: Why is Ghana known as the Fast Fashion Hell?
items.Video_Description:
Join us as we follow the global fast fashion value chain and its harmful impact on Accra's environment, economy, and society. Huge amounts of old clothes and fast-fashion waste are shipped from industrialized countries to Ghana every week. 

But this is only half the story: not far from the waste chaos lies a jewel - the vintage paradise of Ghana, where thrift dreams come true and thousands of people make business with the clothes. Kantamanto is the largest used clothing market in West Africa and a labyrinth.

Who else is behind this?  
Dop: Moritz v. Lüpke
Dop2: Dennis Kyere Danka 
Local Journalist: Isaac Kaledzi

Edit: Wolfgang Siebers / Autornekombinat 
Graphics: Tobias Lenz / Autorenkombinat    
Editorial Support: Nina Suweis/ Birthe Heer / Luisa Böer
/ Leah Engler

items.Video_Description:
Clothing retailers make cheap and fashionable clothing to satisfy the needs of young consumers. Yet, fast fashion has a significant environmental impact. According to the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), the industry is the second-biggest consumer of water and is responsible for about 10% of global carbon emissions – more than all international flights and maritime shipping combined. Unfortunately, fast fashion problems are often overlooked by consumers. @shailurawatyadav

items.Video_Title: Waarom we moeten kappen met fast fashion
items.Video_Description:
We zijn gek op kleding. Maar kan en moet het niet wat minder? Petra Grijzen duikt in de wereld van fast fashion. Hoe komt het dat we zoveel kleding hebben en willen? Welke gevolgen heeft dat? Midden in de Kalverstraat, in het hol van de leeuw, vertelt gedragswetenschapper Reint Jan Renes over wat de winkelstraat doet met de hersenen van de consument. Maar er is ook steeds meer duurzame textiel.

Op ntr.nl/wetenschap vind je de mooiste wetenschapsverhalen van de NTR. We volgen met een kritische blik de ontwikkelingen in de wetenschap en houden je op de hoogte van het laatste wetenschapsnieuws, nieuwe programma's en leuke weetjes.
